conclusion: Two harmonic transverse waves propagate along the positive and negative directions of the x-axis, respectively.
The wave sources are located at x=-0.2m and x=1.2m, with both waves having a wave speed of 0.4m/s and an amplitude of 2m.
The figure shows the images of the two waves at time t=0.
At this moment, the particles P and Q at the equilibrium positions x=0.2m and x=0.8m in the medium just begin to vibrate.
The equilibrium position of particle M is located at x=0.5m.
The question asks at what time do the two waves meet.
The image shows two waves propagating in opposite directions along the x-axis.
Wave from the left source is moving towards the right, and wave from the right source is moving towards the left.
The distance between the two wave sources is 1.2m - (-0.2m) = 1.4m.
The waves meet at the midpoint of this distance, which is 1.4m / 2 = 0.7m from the source at x=-0.2m.
The time it takes for the waves to meet can be calculated using the formula t = d/v, where d is the distance and v is the wave speed.
Substituting the given values, we get t = 0.7m / 0.4m/s = 1.75s.
Therefore, the two waves meet at t = 1.75s.
